context: [2] However, recently an alternative pathway for in vivo NO synthesis has been discovered whereby inorganic nitrate is reduced by oral bacteria to nitrite. [3] This nitrite can be further reduced to NO enzymatically and non-enzymatically. [4] Dietary nitrate is now recognized as an additional and very significant source of NO, whereby a single serving of a nitrate-rich vegetable (eg, spinach) contains more nitrate than what is endogenously formed by all three NOS isoforms combined in 24h. [5] Recent human intervention trials have demonstrated hypotensive and ergonomic effects of dietary nitrate in conjunction with increased blood NO metabolites among multiple healthy and clinical groups.  [1] We present a non-smoking, athletic (body mass index 19 kg/m2) boy, aged 12 years with CF.  [2] The patient had normal lung function (FEV1 = 105%) and pancreatic sufficiency.  [3] This patient initially presented early in life with a history of recurrent chest infections and wheezy episodes.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 'nitrate' and 'Nitrate' refer to the same chemical compound, emphasizing its role in the synthesis of nitric oxide (NO) through a pathway involving oral bacteria. The text highlights dietary nitrate as a significant source of NO, which has implications for health, particularly in terms of hypotensive effects and increased blood NO metabolites. The mention of nitrate-rich vegetables underscores its importance in nutrition and physiology.
